title: Gaza: The Israeli army begins ground assault as Netanyahu is challenged once again
summary: Israelis demonstrated against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is under a judicial investigation, and against the resumption of the war. Yet nothing seems able to halt the hostilities, now that the ceasefire seems definitively broken.

title: Trump signs order to dismantle US Education Department
summary: The president has derided the department as wasteful and polluted by liberal ideology. The plan will preserve its responsibilities for Title I funding for low-income schools, money for children with disabilities and the management of federal student loans.

title: French ex-surgeon Le Scouarnec admits sex abuse of 299 victims
summary: Until now, the retired surgeon had only admitted to his guilt on a case-by-case basis as the proceedings progressed. He is charged with assaulting or raping the patients, many while under anesthesia or waking up after operations, at a dozen hospitals between 1989 and 2014.

title: In North Korea, Kim Jong-un oversees test of latest anti-aircraft missile system
summary: Seoul said last Monday the North had fired 'multiple unidentified ballistic missiles' after it began joint drills involving US soldiers stationed in South Korea, which ended this Thursday. On Thursday, an unnamed spokesperson for the North's defense ministry denounced the military exercise as 'no more than a rehearsal of war of aggression'.

title: IS jailers trial: Life sentence requested for 'one of the most perverse jihadists of the last 10 years'
summary: The maximum sentence was sought for the 'perverse' Mehdi Nemmouche and two other defendants, presumed dead and tried in absentia.

title: Ben & Jerry's: 'The ice cream maker and its independent board, like mission-driven companies, are no longer in vogue'
summary: Unilever, which owns the ice cream chain, fired Ben & Jerry's CEO on March 3. In response, Ben & Jerry's filed a lawsuit against its parent company on Wednesday, March 19. In the US, the tide has turned for companies with a social conscience, observes Philippe Escande, economic editorialist at 'Le Monde.'

title: Kirsty Coventry becomes first woman elected president of International Olympic Committee
summary: The 41-year-old two-time Olympic swimming champion, who is from Zimbabwe, is also the first African to be elected, and the youngest.

title: French researcher denied entry to US for 'expressing personal opinion' on Trump policies
summary: France's research minister expressed 'concern' on Wednesday at this decision by the US authorities. The researcher underwent a random check on arrival, before his computer and phone were searched, a source said.

title: France gets the European Commission to postpone tariffs on American bourbon
summary: Brussels will present measures to respond to Donald Trump's tariffs in mid-April.

title: Tesla cars set on fire in Las Vegas as calls to boycott Musk's company grow worldwide
summary: Since the election of Donald Trump and Elon Musk's arrival as his special advisor, Tesla has been targeted by several acts of vandalism.

title: Ecology: The major renunciation at work in France and around the world
summary: Already marginalized in France and Europe since the start of the war in Ukraine, the defense of climate and the environment finds itself trampled underfoot in the geopolitical chaos created by the Trump administration.

title: Turkey: Massive protests erupt over Istanbul mayor's arrest
summary: Taking to the streets for a second day of protests, thousands of Turkish demonstrators denounced the arrest of Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu in a graft and terror prob, which his party described as a political 'coup.'

title: War in Ukraine: Ceasefire outlines remain uncertain after 'very good' Trump-Zelensky call
summary: In a call on Wednesday, the two men agreed on a restricted version of a truce with Russia, but without removing all ambiguities. Having given up on his plans for Ukrainian minerals, Trump is now offering to take ownership of the country's power plants.

title: On defense and Ukraine, European nations still have no consensus
summary: The leaders of the EU's 27 member states, meeting in Brussels on Thursday, are seeking to reach a compromise despite their differences in resources, ideological orientation and geographical location.

title: 'People tell me that I'm distorting gastronomy': The vegan influencers being harassed
summary: These content creators, fans of meat-free recipes and plant-based alternatives, are constantly accused of betraying culinary tradition. They describe the cyber-harassment targeting them on a daily basis.

title: Godard's 'Breathless' script set to be auctioned
summary: The only known script of the New Wave classic, which includes pages of his handwritten notes, will sold at auction in June said Sotheby's. It's estimated at between €400,000 and €600,000.

title: Fed predicts slowdown but no collapse of US economy amid turbulence of Trump's early days
summary: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, March 19, and revised its growth forecast downward for 2025, to 1.7% from 2.1% in its December 2024 forecast. It now expects inflation to rise slightly to 2.7% this year.

title: Trump's shadow looms over world sport
summary: On Thursday, members of the International Olympic Committee are due to elect Thomas Bach's successor at the head of the organization. They face pressure from the American leader, who is seeking to deconstruct the world sporting order.

title: Sarkozy proclaims his innocence one last time at trial of suspected Libyan campaign funds
summary: 'I have the impression that we started from the premise that Nicolas Sarkozy was guilty and that we had to combine disparate elements,' said the French former president, who faces up to 10 years in prison.

title: Italy's Meloni, caught up in contradictions over transatlantic crisis, benefits from opposition divisions
summary: The Italian prime minister is moderately supportive of Ukraine and European rearmament plans while expressing her support for the Trump administration. In her own country, she must contend with a pacifist movement cutting across different parties, including her own coalition.

title: 'For Africa, the suspension by the US of the AGOA trade agreement would sound like another withdrawal from Washington'
summary: Donald Trump's protectionist credo jeopardizes the continuation of this program of trade preferences benefiting the African continent. Its non-renewal would also have geopolitical implications, writes Marie de Vergès in her column.

title: World's glacier mass shrank again in 2024, says UN
summary: Five of the last six years have seen the most rapid glacier retreat on record, the UN's weather, climate and water agency said, on the inaugural World Day for Glaciers.

title: Five years after Covid, France's 'essential workers' have been forgotten
summary: In 2020, the government said it aimed to better recognize 'essential' jobs – generally grueling, poorly paid and offering no real prospects for advancement – which had helped the country continue functioning during the pandemic. Yet the changes these workers hoped for did not come.

title: Heathrow Airport to close Friday after fire knocks out power to part of London
summary: About 150 people had to be evacuated after a transformer within an electrical substation caught fire in west London. The incident is expected to cause 'significant disruption' for passengers over the coming days.

title: Israel's president expresses concern over steps taken by Netanyahu's government
summary: In an unusual statement, Isaac Herzog said it was 'impossible not to be deeply troubled by the harsh reality unfolding before our eyes'. A few hours later, the cabinet fired the head of Shin Bet, Israel's domestic intelligence agency, in an unprecedented move.

title: Israel expands Gaza ground operation as Hamas fires rockets toward Tel Aviv
summary: The rocket fire from Hamas was its first military response to the growing civilian death toll from Israel's resumption of aerial bombardment and ground operations in the Gaza Strip this week.

title: Sudan army retakes presidential palace
summary: Sudanese army troops recaptured the presidential palace from the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces on Friday.

title: Trump begins dismantling the Department of Education
summary: On Thursday, the US president signed an executive order targeting this department. Unable to abolish it outright without Congressional approval, Donald Trump intends to drastically restrict its prerogatives in favor of the states.

title: Gisèle Pelicot will release her memoir, 'A Hymn to Life,' in 2026: 'I now want to tell my story in my own words'
summary: Pelicot, 72, won international acclaim last year for her courage during the trial of her former husband for orchestrating her mass rape while they were married. A court in southern France in December sentenced Dominique Pelicot, 72, to 20 years for drugging and raping her and inviting dozens of men to do the same for almost a decade.

title: What would France look like at +4°C? More heatwaves, 'tropical nights' and intense rain
summary: In a new report, France's national weather service describes how France's climate would change if current climate policies continue. 'It's another country,' according to climatologist Davide Faranda.

title: Rearming Europe: Brussels grapples with prospect of new large-scale loan
summary: Ahead of Friedrich Merz's arrival in power in Berlin, several leaders are pushing for Eurobonds to fund the continent's defense. The European People's Party, the leading political force within the European institutions, is in favor 'if necessary.'

title: Israel defense minister threatens to annex parts of Gaza
summary: Hundreds of people, including children, have been killed since Israel broke the ceasefire. Now the country is ramping up its assault on Gaza.

title: German parliament approves massive spending package
summary: Friedrich Merz pushed the Bundesrat to vote on the spending package, which would make the country less reliant on defense from the US, before coming into power.

title: Cartoonist accuses French Education Ministry of censorship for canceling his 'Beauty and the Beast'
summary: A comic book version of the 18th-century tale was supposed to be gifted to all children entering middle school this summer. But at the last minute, officials canceled its printing. Cartoonist Jul compared the move to 'Trump and his administration.'

title: Death toll from Serbia's station roof collapse in November rises to 16
summary: The collapse of a train station canopy in the city of Novi Sad in November 2024 killed 15 people. Now a 16th victim has died of his injuries.

title: 'Essential workers,' the forgotten victims of the Covid-19 crisis
summary: Applauded during the lockdowns, celebrated by the president, these indispensable but poorly-paid workers, whose tasks are often arduous have not seen their situation improve, for want of political will.

title: France court to rule in IS Syria case of French jihadist: 'I will never apologize'
summary: Mehdi Nemmouche, 39, is charged with holding four journalists captive more than a decade ago in Syria. He is already in prison after a Belgian court jailed him for life in 2019 for killing four people at a Jewish museum in May 2014. Nemmouche was brought up in the French foster system and became radicalized in prison before going to Syria.

title: Trump's return is pushing India and the EU closer together
summary: Despite differing positions on Russia, Brussels and New Delhi have resumed negotiations on a trade agreement that was suspended in 2013.

title: A destitute Osaka district faces erasure
summary: Authorities aim to 'gentrify' Kamagasaki, once Japan's largest day laborer district, by displacing the many homeless who have sought refuge there.

title: Macron announces new Ukraine 'coalition' summit in Paris on March 27
summary: The French President, together with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, has been leading efforts to form a coalition in support of Ukraine since US President Donald Trump opened direct negotiations with Russia last month.

title: French museum uncovers in storage picture by Renaissance woman master
summary: The painting, 'Portrait of a Gentleman, his Daughter and a Servant,' is now attributed to Lavinia Fontana, one of the very first women to make a career out of painting in Western art. It will now be a centerpiece of the collection of the Musée de la Chartreuse in Douai.

title: The two opposing views of October 7 and its aftermath
summary: Depending on whether you see the terrorist massacre as an episode in a conflict that has been going on since 1948 or as the start of a new era that abolishes previous parameters, the perception of the war between Israel and Hamas changes radically.

title: Kirsty Coventry at the head of the International Olympic Committee, a powerful symbol for world sport
summary: The former Zimbabwean swimmer became the first-ever female IOC president on March 20. This is a break with tradition for the world's supreme sporting body, renowned for its conservatism, and confirms the influence of outgoing president Thomas Bach.
